DOC.HEAD: Science Contest Reverses Course, Accepts Late Entries
DOC.TEXT: The Westinghouse national science contest for high school seniors bent the rules today and agreed to accept 90 entries that arrived late because of a screw-up by Federal Express. ``It just wasn't fair, so we're going to admit them,'' said Westinghouse Electric Corp. spokesman Charles Carroll in Pittsburgh. The box of 90 entries from students at Stuyvesant High School in New York City was due in Washington on Friday but got there Monday. Seventy other Stuyvesant entries sent in a separate batch at the same time arrived before the deadline. Carol Luszcz, program director for the prestigious Westinghouse Science Talent Search, initially said the deadline had been clear and ``we don't make exceptions.'' But Federal Express admitted it misrouted the box of entries and sent Westinghouse an affidavit to that effect, said Armand Schneider, a spokesman for the overnight delivery service. News that their entries were disqualified had dashed the students' dreams of college scholarships. ``I cried,'' said Ming Ling Peng, 17. ``It's the ticket to college for most of us.'' Stuyvesant is nationally known for academic excellence. Each year, its students reach the semifinals or better of the talent search, which began in 1942. ``We take extra courses at Columbia and N.Y.U.,'' Miss Peng said of New York University. ``I know someone who did a physics paper he had been working on since eighth grade.'' Eileen Finkelstein, whose son Steven's project was late, said he was ``devastated'' at being disqualified. ``Why should their blood, sweat and tears go down the drain?'' Mrs. Finkelstein asked. ``These kids are the creme de la creme of the New York system. These are 90 kids who had no control over what was done to them. Certainly rules can be changed a little bit. We're talking about children's destinies.''
